version.body:
This patch adds a :variable_name option for use when rendering collections using partials. It allows you to do something like:
render :partial => 'some_partial_name', :collection => @people, :variable_name => "person"
version.body-html:
This patch adds a :variable_name option for use when rendering collections using partials. It allows you to do something like:

render :partial => 'some_partial_name', :collection => @people, :variable_name => "person"
version.title: :variable_name option added to render :partial .. :collection

version.body:
If your partial is called _item, why not just do:
blah ||= item
at the top of your partial?
version.body-html:
If your partial is called _item, why not just do:

blah ||= item

at the top of your partial?
version.title: :variable_name option added to render :partial .. :collection

version.body:
Because that line isn't going to mean much to the reader and will just add noise. Say I have a partial for product images that is for admin pages only - it contains controls that allow you to delete the image. A logical name for the partial would be _admin_product_image. So, using your scheme you would have:
product_image ||= admin_product_image
I can't really see any compelling reason for doing that over :variable_name.
version.body-html:
Because that line isn't going to mean much to the reader and will just add noise. Say I have a partial for product images that is for admin pages only - it contains controls that allow you to delete the image. A logical name for the partial would be _admin_product_image. So, using your scheme you would have:

product_image ||= admin_product_image

I can't really see any compelling reason for doing that over :variable_name.
version.title: :variable_name option added to render :partial .. :collection

version.body:
For anyone who can read ruby and knows the rails api, this is not really noise. IMO.
Doing it your way means you would have to add that variable everywhere you called the partial. In your example that doesn't seem to matter, but it condones a bad practice. Encapsulation and DRY would suggest pushing what amounts to a config variable do the stack as far as possible.
Your example might be better served if you create an admin namespace and put the partial in there. In which case the partial is still named product_image.
version.body-html:
For anyone who can read ruby and knows the rails api, this is not really noise. IMO.

Doing it your way means you would have to add that variable everywhere you called the partial. In your example that doesn't seem to matter, but it condones a bad practice. Encapsulation and DRY would suggest pushing what amounts to a config variable do the stack as far as possible.

Your example might be better served if you create an admin namespace and put the partial in there. In which case the partial is still named product_image.
version.title: :variable_name option added to render :partial .. :collection

version.body: You make a good point with regards to DRY. I think I now agree - this patch isn't all that. What can I say - it seemed like a good idea late last night!
version.body-html: You make a good point with regards to DRY. I think I now agree - this patch isn't all that. What can I say - it seemed like a good idea late last night!
version.title: :variable_name option added to render :partial .. :collection

version.body: I think it's a great idea, Simon! I've been wanting this for a long time. I'd just suggest using :as instead of :variable_name. Thanks for working on this.
version.body-html: I think it's a great idea, Simon! I've been wanting this for a long time. I'd just suggest using :as instead of :variable_name. Thanks for working on this.
version.title: :variable_name option added to render :partial .. :collection

version.body:
Can you also add this to ActionView::Base#render and tests ?
Thanks.
version.body-html:
Can you also add this to ActionView::Base#render and tests ?

Thanks.
version.title: :variable_name option added to render :partial .. :collection

version.body: (from [2b43620e3c1352028f19550fcde4632d65cbd191]) Add :as option to render a collection of partials with a custom local variable name. [#509 state:resolved] [Simon Jefford, Pratik Naik] http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/2b43620e3c1352028f19550fcde4632d65cbd191
version.body-html:
(from [2b43620e3c1352028f19550fcde4632d65cbd191]) Add :as option to render a collection of partials with a custom local variable name. [#509 state:resolved] [Simon Jefford, Pratik Naik]

http://github.com/rails/rails/co...
version.title: :variable_name option added to render :partial .. :collection

Committed after making several changes.
Thanks.

Thanks.

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
